emerging_technologies.name: AI-Driven Autonomous Codebase Management
emerging_technologies.description: A system where AI not only assists but fully manages software codebases, including version control, refactoring, and deployment.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Enhances software reliability and reduces human error, potentially leading to job displacement in coding roles.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Adoption will depend on trust in AI systems, the need for human oversight, and the speed of AI learning from past coding projects.

emerging_technologies.name: Blockchain-Enhanced Neural Interfaces
emerging_technologies.description: Integration of blockchain for secure and private data handling in neural interfaces, ensuring user data privacy and consent.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Promotes user control over personal brain data, but raises concerns about data integrity and the ethics of neural data ownership.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Regulatory acceptance of blockchain for medical data, public understanding of blockchain, and advancements in neural interface technology.

emerging_technologies.name: Space-Based Solar Power Stations
emerging_technologies.description: Construction of solar power stations in space to capture solar energy without atmospheric interference, transmitting it back to Earth.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Could drastically reduce reliance on non-renewable energy, but requires significant investment and international cooperation.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Technological feasibility, cost reduction in space travel, and global energy policy changes.

emerging_technologies.name: Real-Time Collaborative AI Development
emerging_technologies.description: AI tools that facilitate real-time coding sessions, offering suggestions and automating parts of the development process across teams.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Enhances productivity and learning in software development, but may lead to a divide between AI-enhanced and traditional developers.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Software companies' willingness to integrate AI deeply into their workflow and the evolution of developer education to include AI tools.

mainstream_technologies.name: AI-Assisted Cybersecurity
mainstream_technologies.description: AI systems that continuously learn and adapt to new threats, providing real-time protection against cyber attacks.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Widely adopted by both private and public sectors due to the increasing sophistication of cyber threats.

mainstream_technologies.name: Autonomous Electric Vehicles
mainstream_technologies.description: Fully autonomous vehicles powered by electricity, integrating seamlessly into smart city infrastructures.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Mass adoption in urban environments, with regulatory frameworks evolving to support their integration.

epoch_themes.description: The period where AI significantly augments human capabilities across various sectors, enhancing productivity and decision-making.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Creates new job roles while potentially displacing others, necessitates new educational models, and raises ethical questions about AI's role in decision-making.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Increased investment in AI, with a focus on ethical AI development, explainable AI, and AI for social good.

epoch_themes.description: An era where technology advancements focus on sustainable living both on Earth and in space exploration.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Promotes a shift towards green technologies, potentially leading to new economic models based on space resources.
epoch_themes.global_trends: International cooperation on space projects, push towards zero carbon emissions, and sustainable urban planning.
